# Template: Letter Before Action - Contentious Probate

<!-- 
  Purpose: Formal pre-action letter complying with CPR Practice Direction on Pre-Action Conduct.
  Usage: Before issuing proceedings, after informal approaches exhausted.
  Critical: Must provide sufficient detail for informed response and demonstrate compliance with pre-action requirements.
-->

---

**[Your Firm's Letterhead]**

**Our Ref:** [Matter reference]  
**Your Ref:** [If known]  
**Date:** [Date]

**BY [FIRST CLASS POST / RECORDED DELIVERY / EMAIL]**

[Recipient Name]  
[Title]  
[Firm Name if solicitor]  
[Address Line 1]  
[Address Line 2]  
[City, Postcode]

Dear [Sir/Madam / Mr./Mrs./Ms. Surname],

---

## LETTER BEFORE ACTION

## RE: Estate of [Full Name of Deceased], deceased  
**Date of Death:** [Date of death]  
**Date of Birth:** [Date of birth]  
**Last Address:** [Address]

**Our Client:** [Client's full name and address]

---

### 1. Introduction and Purpose

This is a **Letter Before Action** sent in accordance with the Practice Direction on Pre-Action Conduct and Protocols.

We write on behalf of our client, [Client name], [to challenge the validity of the purported will dated [date] / to make a claim for reasonable financial provision from the estate under the Inheritance (Provision for Family and Dependants) Act 1975 / to claim a beneficial interest in [property/asset] / *specify claim type*].

The purpose of this letter is to:

1. Set out the basis of our client's claim clearly and concisely
2. Enable you to understand and investigate the claim
3. Encourage early resolution without the need for proceedings
4. Comply with the court's requirements for pre-action conduct

**If we do not receive a satisfactory response within the timescale set out below, we have instructions to issue court proceedings without further notice.**

---

### 2. Parties and Their Interest

**Our Client:**

[Client full name] is [relationship to deceased, e.g., "the son/daughter/spouse"]. [He/She] has standing to bring this claim because:

[SELECT APPROPRIATE:]

- [He/She] was a beneficiary under a previous will dated [date]
- [He/She] would be entitled to benefit under the rules of intestacy
- [He/She] is a [spouse/civil partner/child/dependant] of the deceased and entitled to claim under the Inheritance Act 1975
- [He/She] was promised/assured [describe assurance] and relied to [his/her] detriment
- [Other basis of standing]

**You/Your Client:**

[You are / Your client, [name], is] [the executor named in the purported will dated [date] / the person in possession of the will / the beneficiary under the disputed will / *describe*].

[A Grant of Probate was obtained on [date] from the [name] Probate Registry / We understand you are applying for a grant / No grant has yet been obtained].

---

### 3. Brief Background and Chronology

**The Deceased:**

[Deceased's name] died on [date] aged [age]. At the date of death [he/she] was [marital status] [to [name], who [survived/predeceased] [him/her]].

The deceased had [number] children: [names and brief details of children and other close family].

**Estate:**

The estate comprises [brief description of main assets]. The approximate gross value is £[amount] [with net value after liabilities of approximately £[amount]].

**Testamentary Documents:**

[SELECT APPROPRIATE:]

**[For validity challenge:]**
- Will dated [date 1]: [Brief description of provisions - our client's position under this will]
- Will dated [date 2] (disputed): [Brief description of provisions - comparison to earlier will]

**[For Inheritance Act claim:]**
- [Will dated [date] provides [describe provision for client / makes no provision for client]]
- [OR] The deceased died intestate

**Key Events:**

| Date | Event |
|------|-------|
| [Date] | [Event, e.g., "Earlier will executed - client to receive X"] |
| [Date] | [Event, e.g., "Deceased diagnosed with dementia"] |
| [Date] | [Event, e.g., "Disputed will executed"] |
| [Date] | [Event, e.g., "Deceased died"] |
| [Date] | [Event, e.g., "Grant of Probate obtained"] |
| [Date] | [Event, e.g., "Our initial letter requesting information"] |
| [Date] | [Event, e.g., "Your response / No response received"] |

---

### 4. Basis of Claim

#### [SELECT AND CUSTOMIZE APPROPRIATE SECTION(S):]

---

#### [OPTION A: LACK OF TESTAMENTARY CAPACITY]

**Claim:**

Our client contends that the deceased lacked testamentary capacity when executing the will dated [date].

**Legal Basis:**

The test for testamentary capacity is set out in *Banks v Goodfellow* (1870) LR 5 QB 549. The testator must:

1. Understand the nature of making a will and its effects
2. Understand the extent of the property being disposed of
3. Comprehend and appreciate the claims to which they ought to give effect
4. Not be affected by any disorder of mind that perverts their sense of right or prevents the exercise of natural faculties

**Factual Basis:**

At the time the disputed will was executed, the deceased:

- Was aged [age] and suffering from [medical condition(s)]
- Had been diagnosed with [specific diagnoses] on [dates]
- Was taking medication including [list medications that may affect capacity]
- Was exhibiting symptoms including [describe symptoms: confusion, memory loss, inability to recognize family, etc.]
- [Had been assessed as lacking capacity for [other purposes] / Was subject to [LPA/Court of Protection order]]

**Evidence:**

Evidence supporting lack of capacity includes:

1. Medical records from [GP/hospital/care home] showing [summary]
2. [Expert medical opinion from Dr. [name], Consultant [specialty]]
3. Witness evidence from [names] who observed [deceased's condition]
4. [Care home records showing level of care required]
5. [Financial records showing inability to manage affairs]

The will was not prepared in compliance with the "golden rule" for taking instructions from elderly or vulnerable testators.

---

#### [OPTION B: WANT OF KNOWLEDGE AND APPROVAL]

**Claim:**

Our client contends that the deceased did not know and approve the contents of the will dated [date].

**Legal Basis:**

Where suspicious circumstances exist, the propounder of the will must prove affirmatively that the testator knew and approved the contents (*Fulton v Andrew* (1875) LR 7 HL 448).

**Suspicious Circumstances:**

The following suspicious circumstances exist:

1. **Substantial benefit to [name]:** [Describe how beneficiary benefits and their relationship/involvement]
2. **Deceased's vulnerability:** [Age, health, dependence on beneficiary]
3. **Preparation circumstances:** [E.g., beneficiary instructed solicitor, was present at execution, testator did not read will]
4. **Deviation from previous intentions:** [Unexplained change from previous will or stated intentions]
5. **[Other suspicious circumstances]**

**Evidence:**

- Previous will dated [date] showing [compare provisions]
- Evidence that [beneficiary] [was present when will prepared / gave instructions / isolated deceased from family]
- Witness evidence regarding [deceased's understanding / preparation circumstances]
- [Solicitor's file showing inadequate instructions / lack of capacity assessment]

---

#### [OPTION C: UNDUE INFLUENCE]

**Claim:**

Our client contends that the will dated [date] was procured by the undue influence of [name of alleged influencer].

**Legal Basis:**

Undue influence in the probate context requires proof that the will was executed as a result of coercion amounting to the overpowering of the volition of the testator (*Hall v Hall* (1868) LR 1 P&D 481; *Edwards v Edwards* [2007] EWHC 1119 (Ch)).

**Factual Basis:**

[Name of influencer] exercised undue influence over the deceased by:

1. **Relationship and power imbalance:** [Describe relationship - e.g., daughter, carer, financial adviser]
2. **Vulnerability of deceased:** [Age, health, dependence, isolation]
3. **Acts of coercion:**
   - [Specific acts: e.g., isolating from family, controlling access, threats, manipulation]
   - [Timeline of controlling behavior]
4. **Result:** [How the will differs from what would be expected without undue influence]

**Evidence:**

- Witness statements from [family members / carers / neighbors] describing [isolation / controlling behavior]
- Evidence of [financial abuse / dependency]
- Medical evidence of [vulnerability]
- Documentary evidence of [restricting contact / controlling correspondence]

---

#### [OPTION D: FRAUD / FORGERY / WANT OF DUE EXECUTION]

**Claim:**

Our client contends that:

[SELECT:]
- The will is a forgery and was not signed by the deceased
- The will was procured by fraud [describe nature of fraud]
- The will was not duly executed in accordance with s.9 Wills Act 1837

**Legal and Factual Basis:**

[FOR FORGERY:]
- The signature on the will dated [date] is not the deceased's genuine signature
- [Handwriting expert evidence available from [name]]
- [Reasons to doubt authenticity: e.g., deceased was hospitalized/incapacitated at purported date of execution]

[FOR FRAUD:]
- The deceased was fraudulently induced to execute the will by [describe fraudulent misrepresentation]
- [Specific facts of fraud]

[FOR WANT OF DUE EXECUTION:]
- The will was not executed in compliance with s.9 Wills Act 1837 because:
  - [The testator did not sign in the presence of two witnesses present at the same time]
  - [The witnesses did not attest in the presence of the testator]
  - [Other defect in execution]

**Evidence:**

[List evidence supporting the claim]

---

#### [OPTION E: INHERITANCE (PROVISION FOR FAMILY AND DEPENDANTS) ACT 1975]

**Claim:**

Our client makes a claim for reasonable financial provision from the estate under the Inheritance (Provision for Family and Dependants) Act 1975.

**Client's Status:**

Our client is [a surviving spouse/civil partner / a former spouse who has not remarried / a child of the deceased / a person treated as a child of the family / a person being maintained by the deceased].

**Current Provision:**

Under [the will dated [date] / the intestacy rules], our client [receives [describe provision] / receives no provision].

This provision is not reasonable financial provision for our client.

**Factors Under Section 3:**

The court must consider the factors set out in s.3 Inheritance Act 1975. In this case:

1. **Financial resources and needs:**
   - Our client's financial position: [Income £X, capital £Y, liabilities £Z]
   - [Health issues / disability requiring care]
   - [Housing needs]
   - Other beneficiaries' positions: [Summarize]

2. **Obligations and responsibilities:**
   - [Deceased's obligations to client as [spouse/child/dependant]]
   - [Client's dependency on deceased - e.g., financial support of £X per month]
   - [Deceased's obligations to other beneficiaries]

3. **Size and nature of estate:**
   - Net estate approximately £[amount]
   - [Composition: property £X, investments £Y, etc.]

4. **Any physical or mental disability:**
   - [Client suffers from [condition] requiring [support]]

5. **Any other relevant matter:**
   - [Length of marriage / relationship to deceased]
   - [Contributions to deceased's welfare / estate]
   - [Deceased's reasons for provisions (if known)]

**[FOR SPOUSE/CIVIL PARTNER:]**

6. **Additional factors for spouse:**
   - Age: [age]
   - Duration of marriage: [X years]
   - Contribution to welfare of family: [describe]
   - Provision on divorce: [Compare - on divorce client would have received approximately £X under [equal sharing / needs-based approach]]

**Relief Sought:**

Our client seeks reasonable financial provision from the estate, specifically:

- [Lump sum payment of £X]
- [Transfer of property at [address]]
- [Periodical payments of £X per month/year]
- [Combination of above]

**Time Limit:**

This claim is being brought within 6 months of the Grant of Probate [OR requires the court's permission as it is brought more than 6 months after the Grant - permission is sought because [reasons for delay]].

---

#### [OPTION F: PROPRIETARY ESTOPPEL / CONSTRUCTIVE TRUST]

**Claim:**

Our client claims [a beneficial interest in [property/asset] / that the estate holds [property/asset] on constructive trust for our client / estoppel-based relief].

**Legal Basis:**

[For proprietary estoppel, the requirements are:]
1. A clear and unambiguous assurance or representation
2. Reliance on that assurance
3. Detriment suffered as a result
4. Unconscionability (*Thorner v Major* [2009] UKHL 18)

**Factual Basis:**

1. **Assurance/Representation:**
   - On [dates], the deceased [told client / represented to client] that [specific statements, e.g., "the farm will be yours," "I'm leaving the house to you"]
   - [These assurances were made on [multiple occasions / in the presence of [witnesses]]]

2. **Reliance:**
   - In reliance on these assurances, our client [describe acts of reliance]
   - Our client reasonably believed the assurances and acted accordingly

3. **Detriment:**
   - As a result, our client [worked on the farm without payment for X years / gave up career opportunities / made financial contributions / provided care]
   - The value of this detriment is approximately £[quantify if possible]

4. **Unconscionability:**
   - It would be unconscionable for [the estate / you / your client] to resile from these assurances given the detrimental reliance

**Evidence:**

- Witness statements from [names] who heard the assurances
- Documentary evidence [letters, cards mentioning promises]
- Financial records showing [contributions / lack of payment]
- Evidence of [work done / care provided / opportunities foregone]

---

### 5. Alternative Claims

[IF APPLICABLE:]

In the alternative, and without prejudice to the primary claim, our client also claims:

[State alternative basis - e.g., if validity challenge fails, Inheritance Act claim in the alternative]

---

### 6. Remedy Sought

Our client seeks the following relief:

**[SELECT AS APPROPRIATE:]**

**[For validity challenge:]**
1. A declaration that the purported will dated [date] is invalid
2. [Pronouncement for the will dated [earlier date] / Administration on intestacy]
3. An order that you [deliver up the invalid will / pass over the invalid grant]
4. Costs
5. [Any injunctive relief if appropriate]

**[For Inheritance Act:]**
1. An order for reasonable financial provision comprising:
   - [Lump sum of £X]
   - [Transfer of property]
   - [Periodical payments]
2. Costs
3. [Interim provision pending final hearing]

**[For proprietary estoppel:]**
1. A declaration that [property] is held on [constructive trust / subject to estoppel-based interest] for our client
2. An order for transfer of [property] to our client
3. [Alternatively, monetary compensation of £X]
4. Costs

---

### 7. Supporting Documents

We enclose the following documents in support of this claim:

1. [Copy of will dated [date] under which client benefited]
2. [Copy of disputed will dated [date]]
3. [Medical records / expert report - overview]
4. [Chronology of events]
5. [Schedule of client's financial position (for Inheritance Act claims)]
6. [Other key documents]

[Additional documents can be provided upon request or are available for inspection.]

---

### 8. Response Required

We require you to respond substantively to this letter within **[14 / 21] days** of the date of this letter.

Your response should:

1. Confirm whether you accept or dispute the claim
2. If the claim is disputed, provide detailed reasons
3. Identify what facts (if any) are agreed
4. Identify what documents are available or will be disclosed
5. State whether you are prepared to engage in Alternative Dispute Resolution
6. [For Inheritance Act claims: Provide details of estate assets and values, other beneficiaries' positions]

**Failure to respond adequately to this letter may have costs consequences if proceedings are issued.**

---

### 9. Alternative Dispute Resolution

Before incurring the costs and uncertainty of litigation, our client is willing to consider Alternative Dispute Resolution (ADR), including:

- **Mediation:** Independent mediator to facilitate negotiated settlement
- **Early Neutral Evaluation:** Expert assessment of merits to assist settlement
- **Round-table negotiation:** Direct negotiation between parties and lawyers

We believe ADR could resolve this matter more quickly and cost-effectively than litigation. The court will require parties to engage seriously with ADR options.

**Please confirm whether you are willing to engage in ADR and, if so, your preferred method.**

If you refuse to engage in ADR, please provide reasons as this may affect any subsequent costs order.

---

### 10. Limitation and Urgency

**[IF RELEVANT - SELECT:]**

**[For Inheritance Act claims:]**
This claim must be brought within 6 months of the Grant of Probate (obtained [date]). The time limit expires on [date]. If agreement cannot be reached quickly, we will need to issue proceedings to protect our client's position.

**[For other claims where urgency:]**
[Explain any limitation or urgency issues]

[If distribution is threatened:]
**Distribution:** We note that [you have indicated / we are concerned] that the estate may be distributed. We require an undertaking that no distribution will be made pending resolution of this claim. If such an undertaking is not provided within [7 days], we will apply to the court for an injunction.

---

### 11. Costs

Our client has incurred costs to date of approximately £[amount].

The estimated costs to trial are £[range].

Under the CPR, the court will consider the parties' conduct in the pre-action phase when deciding who should pay the costs of the proceedings. Unreasonable refusal to:

- Provide information
- Engage in ADR
- Make realistic settlement proposals

may result in costs sanctions.

Our client hopes to resolve this matter without proceedings, which would benefit all parties in terms of costs, stress, and preserving family relationships.

---

### 12. Funding

Our client is funded by [private means / legal expenses insurance / conditional fee agreement / other].

[IF CLIENT NOT UK RESIDENT OR SECURITY FOR COSTS MAY BE SOUGHT:]
Our client is [resident in England and Wales / a UK resident] and [has assets in the jurisdiction / is able to provide security for costs if necessary].

---

### 13. Next Steps if No Satisfactory Response

If we do not receive a satisfactory response within the timescale specified:

1. We have instructions to issue proceedings immediately without further notice
2. This letter will be referred to in any proceedings as evidence of pre-action compliance
3. We will seek our costs of issuing proceedings on an indemnity basis given the clear warning
4. [We will apply for urgent interim relief including [injunction / interim Inheritance Act provision]]

We trust this will not be necessary and that this matter can be resolved through correspondence or ADR.

---

### 14. Reservation of Rights

This letter and any without prejudice discussions that may follow are sent in an attempt to settle this matter without court proceedings. Nothing in this letter should be taken as any admission or waiver of our client's rights, all of which are expressly reserved.

---

We look forward to receiving your substantive response by [date - 14/21 days from date of letter].

If you wish to discuss this matter or require any clarification, please contact [fee earner name] at this office.

---

Yours [faithfully/sincerely],

**[Your Name]**  
**[Your Position]**  
**[Your Firm]**

---

**Enclosures:**
1. [List all enclosures]

**CC:** [Client name]

---

## Drafting Guidance

### Critical Requirements

- **Compliance:** Must comply with Pre-Action Protocol and Practice Direction
- **Clarity:** Claim must be clear enough for informed response
- **Detail:** Sufficient detail to enable recipient to understand and investigate
- **ADR:** Genuine proposal for ADR required
- **Deadline:** Reasonable deadline (14-21 days typically)

### Customization

- Select appropriate sections for type of claim
- Provide specific factual details, not generalizations
- Quantify claims where possible
- Attach key supporting documents
- Tailor to specific circumstances

### Before Sending

- [ ] Client approval obtained
- [ ] All facts verified
- [ ] Supporting documents gathered
- [ ] Costs estimate accurate
- [ ] Limitation position confirmed
- [ ] Settlement parameters discussed with client
- [ ] Peer/supervisor review completed

### After Sending

- [ ] Diarize response deadline
- [ ] File proof of service
- [ ] Prepare for non-response (draft proceedings)
- [ ] Keep client informed
- [ ] Be ready to engage in ADR if proposed
